newsitem.title: UK: FOCUS-Germany to dump oil on fragile world market.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Germany to dump oil on fragile world market.

text.p: World oil markets were looking vulnerable to further price falls as a second country lined up to sell crude on Friday, irrespective of how low prices go.
Crude oil prices have slumped nearly 30 percent this year and look likely to fall further when Germany joins Iraq in chasing an oil sale cash target.
Germany's sales, approved by a cabinet meeting in Bonn on Friday, were likely to amount to just a tenth of the volume of Iraq, but oil market nerves were already frayed and fundamentals fragile.
"It won't help," said Bob Finch, head of trading at Vitol SA, the world's largest independent oil trading and refining company.
Germany this year wants to sell $230 million worth of oil, stockpiled since the late 1970's, to help meet tough financial targets for entry to a single European currency.
It plans to sell 2.8 million barrels in the next few weeks and 7.3 million tonnes (or about 54 million barrels) by the end of 1999.
At current oil prices that would be at least 75,000 barrels per day during the rest of this year, roughly the same as a medium sized oil field in the North Sea.
Brent crude oil, the world benchmark, closed 11 cents higher at $18.07 thanks to a short-lived rally in the gasoline market in the Unied States.
But Brent remains about about $1 below levels at the start of July and traders predict further falls next week.
"The German move is yet another blow to an already bearish market," said John Toalster of SGST Securities.
"The volumes of crude from Germany are relatively small but the fundamentals are finely balanced," said Paul Spedding of Kleinwort Benson in London.

Iraq has moved closer to resuming oil exports under an "oil-for-food" deal with the United Nations and a meeting between U.N. and Baghdad officials on Sunday may finalise the aid plan needed before its crude sales can resume.
Baghdad can sell $2 billion worth of oil by December and the Iraqi oil minister said sales would resume at around 740,000 bpd.
The International Energy Agency confirmed the bearish mood this week saying over the rest of the year markets are "expected to soften appreciably."
Rising oil demand will be offset by rising oil stocks, the Petroleum Finance Company Ltd said.
"The final blow to prices however will be the rapid and concentrated resumption of Iraqi oil sales and the realisation of long expected North Sea output hikes," it said.
Leading upstream consultants Wood MacKenzie see UK North Sea oil output rising by about 300,000 bpd from the third quarter to the fourth.
Despite the bearish outlook towards the end of the year, some dealers believe the short term picture is more balanced.
North Sea output is expected to drop in August due to oil field maintenance and both Saudi Arabia and Nigeria have hiked prices to Western customers for next month.
Crude oil prices in dollars per barrel:
July 11 July 10
(close) (close)
Dated Brent $18.04 $18.06
IPE August Brent $18.07 $17.96
NYMEX August light crude $19.34 $19.21
